docs.lead_paragraph: None of these presidential candidates is likely to be a future candidate or top player in a Republican administration. But some may parlay their prominence into other endeavors, maybe some big bucks.

headline.main: Democrats Take Aim at Romney in New Ad
headline.print_headline: The Ad Campaign: Democrats Take Aim at Romney’s Shifts

docs.abstract: Called "Trapped," it is styled as a parody of a sci-fi movie trailer for "the story of two men trapped in one body."
docs.snippet: Called "Trapped," it is styled as a parody of a sci-fi movie trailer for "the story of two men trapped in one body."

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee on Monday escalated its effort to define Mitt Romney, seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2012, as a flip-flopper with a new ad in five battleground states. Called "Trapped," it is styled as a parody of a sci-fi movie trailer for "the story of two men trapped in one body."

headline.main: Behind the Cover Story: Benoit Denizet-Lewis on Bulldogs

docs.abstract: Benoit Denizet-Lewis discusses the tension between Uga and Handsome Dan, two bulldog mascots, and other issues raised by his cover story.
docs.snippet: Benoit Denizet-Lewis discusses the tension between Uga and Handsome Dan, two bulldog mascots, and other issues raised by his cover story.

docs.lead_paragraph: Benoit Denizet-Lewis, the author of Sunday's cover article on bulldogs, began writing for the magazine in 2002, when he was 26. Since then, he has written six cover articles and numerous features, including his recent piece about his ex-gay friend, Michael Glatze. He is also the author of "America Anonymous: Eight Addicts in Search of a Life."

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich has fleshed out his legal residency plan for long-time illegal immigrants. And it doesn't look good.
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich has fleshed out his legal residency plan for long-time illegal immigrants. And it doesn't look good.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, the editorial board praised Newt Gingrich for breaking from the Republican pack and supporting a path to legal residency for long-time illegal immigrants. Now Mr. Gingrich is starting to flesh out that idea-since he has revived his standing on the right wing of the party and appears to think he's got a shot at the nomination-but it turns out to be much less thoughtful and generous than it appeared during the debate.
